## Introduction

I have on-and-off been a user of the Pomodoro technique, which
is based on splitting your work day into increments of, typically,
25-minute work sessions followed by 5-minute breaks, repeated
say, four times, and then followed by a longer, 15-minute break.

Since I spend most of my workday in front of my computer, using a computer
application has seemed to be the most suitable approach. Unfortunately, there
is a jungle of Pomodoro timers out there, and finding a good one has proven
hard. Before I turned to window managers like i3 and sway,^[Which is what I am
currently using.] I used the [GNOME Pomodoro
Timer](https://gnomepomodoro.org/), which I liked. But ever since I switched
from GNOME, I've been struggling to find a good replacement.

What I have been looking for, specifically, is a Pomodoro timer
that integrates with my status bar (currently waybar) and that
I can control using either keyboard shortcuts or mouse clicks.

There are alternatives that can be used for this problem,
such as

- [waybar-pomodoro-timer](https://github.com/Andeskjerf/waybar-module-pomodoro),
- [Tomato.C](https://github.com/gabrielzschmitz/Tomato.C),
- [potato-c](https://github.com/nimaaskarian/potato-c),
- [waybar-timer](https://github.com/jbirnick/waybar-timer), and
- [uair](https://github.com/metent/uair).

Each of these are great projects, and yet none of them ever
quite fit my use case. So I decided to write my own
Pomodoro timer, which I named **Tomat** (Swedish ðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡ª for tomato).

The main goal of Tomato is to create a simple Pomodoro timer that's
easy to use and configure and that easily integrates with status bars
like waybar. It roughly follows the GNU Philosophy of "Do One Thing
Well", and does not try to be a full-fledged time management
application. It also tries to be as lightweight as possible,
without unnecessary dependencies, and is written in Rust (which helps).

Tomat is designed as a client--server application, where the server
runs in the background and keeps track of the timer state, while
the client is used to interact with the server, e.g., to start
or stop the timer, or to query the current status. This design
makes it easy to integrate Tomat with status bars, as the status
bar can simply call the client to get the current status.

Setup is a little more involved than a simple one-binary
application, but the design makes it easier to handle
persistent state and to interact with multiple clients and
to handle notifications and sounds.

```{mermaid}

%%| fig-align: center
graph TD
    A[Client] -->|Commands| B(Server)
    B -->|Status| A
    B -->|Notifications| C[Notification System] 
    B -->|Sound| D[Sound System]    
```

## Quick Start

Tomat is available on [crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/tomat),
so if you have Rust and Cargo installed, installing it is
as simple as running:

```bash
cargo install tomat
```

To then get going, we need to first start the server:

```{bash}
tomat daemon start
```
